CH4 has "A safe stronghold our God is still". VU has French translation. Chalice lyrics are adapted by Ruth Duck, and Presbyterian Hymnal has some updated lyrics too.

First_line: Be thou my guardian and my guide

References_or_purpose: Gathering; Sending forth; Phil 3:7; Ps 73:25; Ps 16; Ps 27; Ps 63; Prov 1:5-7; Eph 6:10-17; James 1:1-7; 1 Tim 6:6-10; Acts 2:1-21; Joel 2:23-32; Matt 17:1-9; John 9; Phil 3:4b-14
Comments: Most recent hymnals have inclusive language for people, but not for God. The Father imagery fits in this hymn, so I don't mind leaving it there. Note that the High King imagery is historically relevant!
Column_39: Note that the High King imagery is historically relevant!

URW and Chalice are inclusive. Set to the simple tune MERLES TUNE. Cha137 uses the first line as a refrain for a read version of the passage.

Great to get kids involved with finger cymbals or a simple drum beat. PfAS doesn't give a tempo, but StB indicates crotchet (quarter note) = 140.

First_line: Christ will come again
Author: (Wren)
Comments: One of few hymns that talks about sifting the weeds From the wheat. The tune is new, and fits the unusual metre of these words. It should be picked up quite quickly by a singing congregation, but would benefit From a quick lesson before the start of the service. “Christ will come again, God’s justice to complete, to reap the fields of time and sift the weeds From wheat. Then let us passionately care for peace and justice here on earth, and evil’s rage restrain with love, till Christ shall come again”.

First_line: Come now the feast is spread

Comments: Cantor and refrain. Before communion. Maybe a bit long, but you don't need to sing all the verses. This is quite energetic and fun; it feels to me like someone should be dancing around the church, calling everyone in to communion, and the congregation should just dance right back at them!

Comments: This song appears in a few different formats. There is a full-length short song (WWHW) and a short 7 bar refrain (Gather), either would work well as a response. The refrain is exactly the same melody as the short song, but only uses the words "Come O Lord and set us free, come and set us free".

First_line: Creation sings! Each plant and tree
Author: (Leckebusch)
Comments: Thoughtful words about our relationship with the earth and all that is in it. One of very few hymns that connects human creatures with the other creatures of our planet, and questions our desire to control all of earth. Sung to a fairly simple tune, that will need to be sung through once before the congregation joins in.

Comments: A song asking forgiveness for our disdain for the earth and animals.

First_line: Dark is the night / Sing Alleluia

I especially like the last verse “Hope for the poor, release for the captive, Love for the outcast, light for weary eyes; Word that brings life, embracing humanity, Jesus, companion be born into our lives”. It would be particularly good for a Christmas eve service.

There are multiple possible tunes. I like FOR THE BREAD, which is in VU.

I think this might become one of our family's table graces!

WoV also has the traditional Hebrew chorus of "Torah ora torah ora hallelujah" which means "The Lord is light" and would be great to sing; and it's the original words!

Comments: Simple chant "God our protector, keep us in mind, always give strength to your people. For if we could be with you one day in time it is better than a thousand without you" Could be used between a reading of the Psalm, or on its own with or without an instrumental bridge.

First_line: God the Spirit guide and guardian

Comments: Excellent, inclusive Trinitarian lyrics of God's guidance and blessing on leaders in the church community. Set to a variety of well known hymn tunes including HYFRYDOL (my favourite!), JEFFERSON, BLAENWERN and BETHANY

First_line: God to enfold you
Author: (Bell)

Comments: Good simple words celebrating a union of love and service to the tune of "Brother, Sister, Let me serve you".

Author: (Murray)

First_line: God we thank you for our people

First_line: God weeps
God Weeps at love withheld
Author: (Murray)
References_or_purpose: lament; famine; funeral; Ps 10; Isa 10:1-4; Isa 42:2-4; Lk 6:20-31
Column_39: Powerful words. Tune in MV is my preferred tune.

First_line: God Weeps with Us Who Weep and
Author: (Troeger)
Comments: Excellent words, but the tune is not intuitive. Could probably be sung to another tune (8.6.8.6.8.6.8.6). I will try to look this up at some stage.

First_line: God welcomes all
Author: (Bell)

First_line: God when human bonds are broken
Author: (Kaan)
Column_39: These words pick up an unusual theme, and fit really well with this reading. The tune is not familiar, but it works very well and should not be too difficult if a little time is taken to introduce it to your congregation. It can also be sung to MERTON (in WoV) or OMNI DIE which are both more familiar than TiS tune.

First_line: God when I came into this life
Author: (Kaan)
Comments: Excellent words of commitment to a well known shape note tune (LAND OF REST).

First_line: God when I stand
Author: (O'Driscoll)
Comments: Good words; the tune will probably need to be taught, or at least played through before the congregation sings it.

First_line: God who births us
Author: (Ferguson)

First_line: God who blesses new beginnings
Author: (Huxhold)

First_line: God who carved this timeless landscape

Comments: Not wild about the tune, but good words - for Australia and New Zealand

First_line: God who gives to life its goodness

First_line: God who granted faith

First_line: God who has caused to be written
Author: (O'Driscoll)

First_line: God who made the earth and heaven

First_line: God who made the earth the air the sky and sea

First_line: God who remembers

Comments: Excellent words seeking Christian unity, even when times are difficult. Sung to the familiar hymn tune MORNING SONG. Sheet music.

First_line: Great God of earth and heaven

First_line: Great in power
Great is God

First_line: Great is he who's the King of kings

First_line: Great Is The Darkness
Great Is the Lord

First_line: Great is the Lord

Author: (Toolan)

First_line: Great Is the Lord
Author: (Gelineau)

First_line: Great Is the Lord
Author: (Deborah Smith)

First_line: Great is the Lord
Great Is the Lord
Author: (Ewing)

First_line: Great Is The Lord And Most Worthy Of Praise
Author: (McEwen)

First_line: Great is the Lord our God
Author: (Psalter)

First_line: Great is the Love
Author: (Betty Wendelborn From Mechtild of Magdeburg)

First_line: Great is the mystery of faith

Author: (Chisolm)
Column_39: Most sources for this have a very masculine God throughout. The New Century Hymnal does not, so if you would like to sing this hymn, and it is a grand old hymn, please seek out the lyrics in the NCH.

First_line: Great is your faithfulness O God of Jacob
Author: (Maher)
Comments: This rock song is really pretty good. Note that the lyrics on most of Matt Maher's recordings are not the same as in SP&P. I quite like the changes he made for SP&P. The chorus is a bit repetitive, but hey, it bears repeating really.

First_line: Great Is Your Mercy

First_line: Great O Lord

First_line: Great shepherd of your people
Author: (Newton)

First_line: Great sorrow prodded Jairus
Author: (Stilborn)
Comments: A simple storytelling song

First_line: Great Spirit God the things which are yours
Author: (Dakota hymn)
Comments: Good solid lyrics of God's provision. Would work well with a strong drum beat. Native American hymn. An alternate translation to "Many and Great"

First_line: Great Spirit now I pray / Daw-Kee Aim Daw-Tsi-Taw

Hmmm… imagine if Jacob and Esau had learned this when they were growing up!

"Jesus,come! surprise our dullness; Make us willing to receive More than we can yet imagine, All the best you have to give: Let us find your hidden riches, Taste your love,believe,and live!". Two possible tunes (and probably others). Lyrics here (loads a pdf)

It is set as a two part song, but you could use it first as a cantor-led song, with the congregation joining in on the refrain. Then, as the congregation gets to know it, you could build it in complexity. Sounds like it would work well during some candle lighting for prayers.

First_line: Light of the minds that know him

First_line: Light of the world true light divine

First_line: Light of the world you stepped down into darkness

First_line: Light one candle for hope
Comments: Advent Candle Song

First_line: Light one candle to watch for Messiah
Author: (Wold)
Comments: Not wild about the words.

First_line: Light rises in darkness when justice rules our lives
Author: (Kimbrough/ Young)
Comments: A lovely Psalm response. Could be used with a sung or read version of the Psalm. The TiS translation is quite inclusive. It's from the United Methodist Liturgical Psalter (1989).

First_line: Light shone in darkness
Light the Advent Candle
Author: Manalo

First_line: Light the Fire
Author: (McKenna)

First_line: Light The Fire Again
Light transcendent / Peace In Our Time
Author: (Brown)

First_line: Light up the candle
Author: Mills

First_line: Light Up The Fire
Light's abode celestial Salem
Author: (13th Century)

First_line: Light's glittering morn bedecks the sky
Light's reddening dawn gleams through the sky
Like a Bird that spreads her wings
Author: (Dufner)

First_line: Like a Candle
Author: (O'Brien, Ogilvie)

First_line: Like a candle burning wildly
Author: (Mitchell)
Comments: "WE are called to live the passion". Good song. Particularly nice on guitar. Note that the NCYC version has good notes on how to play it on guitar.

First_line: Like A Candle Flame
Author: (Kendrick)

First_line: Like a Child love would send
Author: (Damon)
Comments: Simple song with lovely words about Christ as a child, and Christ's likeness in all kinds of children.

First_line: Like A Child Rests / As a child rests in its mother's arms
Author: (Walker)
Comments: Simple refrain; works well on its own and the verses are good. Note that PfAS and GtG have removed the beautiful extra beat in the 2nd bar, so try not to use that version! It's one of my favourite parts of this song. Listen to the version on the OCP website.

First_line: Like A Child that is quieted is my soul
Author: (Ellenberger)
Comments: A lovely simple refrain. It will work well just with the melody, but there are also some beautiful set harmonies that you could include if you have the singers.

First_line: Like a deer seeking streams of water / Como el ciervo
Author: (Salinas)
Comments: OK.

First_line: Like a father watching over me
Author: HEIDENROSLEIN / Hay
Column_39: I miss this one, but the language is too dated.

First_line: Like a healing stream
Author: (Harding)
Comments: Gentle folksy ballad with a lot of water imagery - healing stream, gentle rain, river strong and mighty sea. Would need to be introduced, but would catch on pretty quickly, I think.

First_line: Like A Lamb
Like a mighty river flowing
Author: (Perry)
Comments: Lovely words.

First_line: Like a mother who has borne us
Author: (Bechtel)
Comments: Very easy and intuitive tune.

First_line: Like a river glorious
Like a River Glorious
Author: (Havergal)

First_line: Like a Rock
Author: (Wehlander / Good)

First_line: Like a sea without a shore
Like A Shepherd he feeds his flock
Author: (Dufford)
Comments: Too masculine

First_line: Like a Shepherd I will feed you / We will rise again
Author: Haas
Comments: Better songs for this passage out there

First_line: Like a Ship That's Toss'd and Driven / The Lord Will Make a Way Somehow (
Comments: I like the version of this on the soundtrack to that Steve Martin movie, the name of which escapes me now.

First_line: Like a tender breath stirring
Like a tree beside the waters
Author: (Martin)
Comments: Good congregational words of richness From the waters. Tune is a little bit tricky, so will need to be introduced. It can also be sung to the more familiar HYFRYDOL.

First_line: Like a tree that's planted by the water
Author: (African American)
Comments: This simple refrain would work well with Psalm 112, even though this book lists it for Psalm 1.

First_line: Like a warm breeze / Building the Kingdom
Author: (Robinson)
Comments: Okay, words are not very interesting

First_line: Like as the deer
Like autumn leaves upon the ground / One by one you call us home
Author: Mann

First_line: Like Burning Incense (Ps 141)
Author: (True)
Comments: A moving arrangement of the Psalm, set to a laid-back jazz-inspired arrangement of the well known hymn tune PICARDY. You could use the refrain on its own as a response to Intercessions. If using the full Psalm, use a cantor for the verses, as the congregation might get confused by the unusual arrangement of the tune.

First_line: Like fireworks in the night
Author: (Fraser)

First_line: Like Miriam who danced to praise
Author: Keithahn
Comments: Probably good. Good words. Dance focus.

First_line: Like rivers in the desert
Like the deer that yearns
Like the murmur of the dove's song

First_line: Like the sun upon my skin / God's mercy

First_line: Like the woman at the well I was seeking / Fill my cup

First_line: Like the woman of old (wellsprings)
Author: (Stewart)

First_line: Like when the Israelites needed the manna

First_line: Lion and lamb lying together
Listen all who hear / Break Open The Word...

First_line: Listen to your Saviour call

First_line: Listening God you hear us when we cannot speak

Litany of the Saints
Litany of the Saints (Walsh)
Litany of the Spirit

First_line: Lo God is here! let us adore

First_line: Lo how a Rose e'er blooming / Behold a rose is growing

First_line: Lo how a Rose e'er blooming / Behold a rose is growing

Comments: A responsive reading and sung response based on a familiar hymn.

First_line: Lo I Am With You to the end of the world
Author: (Iona / Bell)
Comments: Matt 28:20; Maundy Thursday; Communion
Column_39: Simple repetitive verses, in a nice minor key.

First_line: Long ago and far away

Comments: Song for Wisdom. Pretty straightforward.

First_line: Long before the night was born

First_line: Long time ago in Bethlehem / Mary's boy child

First_line: Longing for light we wait in darkness (christ be our light)

Comments: Definitely

First_line: Longing for you in wilderness wasting
Author: (Loukes)

First_line: look
Look and learn From the birds of the air
Look around you

First_line: Look in wonder

First_line: Lord as the earth welcomes showers of rain

First_line: Lord be the rising

First_line: Lord for tomorrow and its needs

First_line: Lord glorify your name

First_line: Lord God almighty Father of all mercies

Comments: This is a lovely song, which can be sung on its own, or as a Psalm refrain, as in URW (use the section "Make your face to shine… loving kindness save me" as the refrain, and the section beginning "But as for me" at the conclusion of the Psalm).

First_line: Make your home in me
Author: (White)
Comments: A simple beautiful invitation. Written by Melbourne songwriter and teacher, Fay White. “If you fly to the point of the day’s sunrise or westward across the sea, if you travel to the uttermost ends of the earth, there I will be; Make your home in me as I make my home in you. I am everywhere that you can be. Make your home in me”. This is quite different to the Vineyard / Josh Young version you can find all over the internet. I can't find a sample of this one, unfortunately.

Comments: Wonderful inclusive words, and a beautiful tune, that for me sounds a lot like "Lord Jesus Christ, Lover of All" so melodically ties Advent in with Maundy Thursday and Good Friday. You may like to sing it this Sunday and leave the last verse until Christmas day. Highly recommended.

First_line: Many faces the young and the old / Gathered as One

It fits this reading particularly well "Lord of infinity, stooping so tenderly, lifts our humanity to the heights of his throne".

First_line: My God my God why why have you forsaken me?
Author: (Ukur / Feliciano)
Comments: This can be sung either as a unison refrain, a tricky 4 part harmony chorale, or an even trickier chant with a solost (or reader). The words said by the reader, or sung by the cantor are quite challenging, and coming more from the perspective of poorer nations. This would be pretty amazing to do. The refrain can be sung in English, Bahasa Indonesian, Pilipino, Mandarin or Thamilz.

First_line: Nearer my God to you
Author: (Adams)
Column_39: I didn’t grow up with this song, so the tune seems kind of sappy and sentimental to me. Having said that, I really like the words in the NCH and it is such an excellent fit for this reading I have listed it “When I am wandering as Jacob did, and in the deepest night, the path is hid, my dreams will bring me, too, nearer my God, to you”. Please note that not all sources have such accessible words (e.g. AoV2 doesn’t). More traditional lyrics are here, and are almost nothing like the version in the NCH!

Comments: A classic song of thanks. The masculine God is onl y present in the last verse (in TiS, AHB and AoV1).  A few simple substitutions can make it inclusive, too. Since this is in the Public Domain you can change the lyrics as you feel is appropriate. Chalice hymnal has great inclusive words.

First_line: Now the star of Christmas

Comments: A multifaith epiphany song: "Where the three kings travel, three great faiths arise: Jesus Christ for Christians, Jesus, Judah's son, Prophet for the Muslim, wisdom in each one". Some congregations will find this a bit too much, but others will find much to celebrate in this song.
Column_39: Can also be sung to NOEL NOUVELET if you don't want to try a new tune.

First_line: O God of Earth and Space
Author: Leoni
Comments:
Terrific words by Jane Parker Huber to a well known Jewish hymn tune. "Wherever freedom reigns, where sin is overthrown,
Where justice fused with mercy rules, there you are known.
Give us the courage clear, to make the earth a home,
For all to live in harmony, in Christ’s shalom." Highly recommended.

First_line: Praise the God who changes places
Comments: I like the joy of the tune written by William Rowan (BOE) for this song (TiS 178). Lyrics and sign language here (scroll to the bottom for the lyrics). Sample here, to a different tune. Some older versions, particularly in all the Gather hymnals use the chorus of "Stand Up Friends" instead of "Friends, Stand Strong". Wren changed the lyrics to the latter at the request of a community member in a wheelchair. I think this is an excellent change!

Column_39: GA, WoV and VU has made this gender inclusive for God by simply replacing "his righteousness" with "God's righteousness" or "its righteousness", which each have slightly different meanings. Easy, really. Even some of the old hymns like the 1982 Hymnal are inclusive! And, "We do not live by bread alone".

The words are particularly lovely for the verses. "come to me, come to me and drink deeply, freely, taste and see my love". Inclusive too.

First_line: The word of God is planted

Author: (Dufner / Hurd)
Comments: Great words. For example "The Word of God is source and seed; It comes to die and sprout and grow. So make your dark earth welcome warm; Root deep the grain God bent to sow." The words also fit with the Ps, so you might want to sing this song if you have access to it. There's a very helpful commentary including the lyrics of the hymn here. (Thanks to Bob Gardiner at crossbeams for providing this link).
Column_39: I'm not wild about the tune though.

First_line: The Word of Life
The Word whom earth and sea and sky
The Works of the Lord Are Created in Wisdom
Comments: These words are really good and taLk about the beauty of creation revealing the wisdom of God. Unfortunately, the images of God are exclusively masculine, but I think this could easily be changed. The song is set to the familiar and joyous tune KREMSER. "The works of the Lord are created in wisdom; We view the earth's wonders and call (him) to mind. We hear what (he) says in the world we discover. And God shows (his) glory in all that we find".

First_line: We are climbing Jacob's ladder
Author: (African-American)
Comments: A traditional well-known favourite in some circles; NCH replaces “Soldiers of the cross” with “bearers of the cross”. Sample here. (GIA website). Note that not all sources are as accessible. Lyrics of a more traditional version here. Note there are also many recordings of this song (e.g. Pete Seeger, Sweet Honey in the Rock, Paul Robeson, Bruce Springsteen, Jane Siberry) that you may also want to use; it's also interesting to see how each of these singers has altered the lyrics.

First_line: When From the darkness comes no light

Comments: This is a great Christmas season song to a very easy tune to sing. I especially love verse 3 "Wise men, they called them, earnest astrologers, watching for meaning in the moving stars, science or fancy, learned or laughable, theirs was a vision that was brought to pass. Sing all you wise men, dance all the scientists whether your theories are false or true. God uses knowledge, God uses ignorance. God at his coming had a need of you". Those who know what my day job is will understand why I like this so much.

Column_39: Good words based on Song of Songs / Song of Solomon and Ruth. It would work well with a cantor, though I'm not sure how it would fit in a standard worship service (as opposed to a wedding). Sound, lyric and sheet music (refrain only) sample here.

I really like the tune MONK'S GATE. Particularly nice with light instrumentation. A violin / flute and a drum may be all you need for this.

Sound and sheet music sample here (note the Gather hymnal song number before clicking). The CH4 version is a little clunky.

First_line: You have made us from above
You have passed by
You have put on Christ / Baptism
Author: (Hughes)
Column_39: Nice little tune. Not all versions are gender inclusive. It can also be sung as a round (coming in at the start of each bar), which is not clear from most editions. Glory to God has two verses ("you have put on Christ", then "we have put on Christ") which I particularly like, as it reminds us of our own baptism. I would love to hear this pealing around the congregation at a baptism!
